isis.stitle: SINGLE REDUCTION CARRIERS: ROCKWELL - REASSEMBLE - INSTALL TWO-PIECE SPIGOT BEARING ASSEMBLIES

note.para: This procedure applies to some 160 Series single rear axles and rear rear tandem axles. These axles may also use a one-piece spigot bearing with a snap ring retainer.
The inner race of two-piece spigot bearings must be staked in place on RS series rear axles. Before you stake the pinion, you must heat the pinion stem to soften it.
A peen tool kit is available (refer to SPECIAL TOOLS) which includes everything required to perform this procedure.

step1.para: Apply two stripes of temperature indicating liquid on the pinion stem from the top to the bottom ( Figure 61). Apply a green stripe to indicate 400°F and a blue stripe to indicate 500°F

figure.caption: Figure 61. Apply Temperature Indicating Liquid on Pinion Stem

step1.para: Put the heating shield over the pinion stem so that you can see the temperature indicating liquid through the hole in the shield ( Figure 62).

figure.caption: Figure 62. Put Heating Shield Over Pinion Stem

warning.para: To protect yourself from injury, wear safety glasses when you do Steps 3-6. Wear heat resistant gloves while you do Steps 3 and 4.

caution.para: Do not heat the pinion stem without the heat shield in place. Also, do not overheat the pinion stem or you will weaken the metal which can cause early failure. Correct heating will take approximately 25-35 seconds, depending on how hot the torch is.

step1.para: Light and adjust the torch until the white part of the flame is approximately 1/4 inch long. Keep the white part of the flame approximately 1/8 inch from the top of the stem ( Figure 63). Move the flame around the outer diameter of the top of the pinion stem. The green temperature indicating liquid will turn black before the blue liquid does. Heat the stem until the blue liquid turns black at a point in the middle of the window.

figure.caption: Figure 63. Keep White Part of Torch Flame 1/8 Inch From Top of Stem

step1.para: Remove the flame and the heat shield from the pinion. Let the pinion air cool for 10 minutes. Use a razor blade to remove the temperature indicating liquid.

caution.para: Do not press or hit directly on the new inner race in Step 5 or you will damage the bearing.

step1.para: Use a press, if available, or a brass hammer to install the new inner race. Use the old inner race as a sleeve. The race is completely seated when you cannot fit a 0.002 inch feeler gauge between the race and the pinion shoulder.

note.para: If you cannot hold the races in place, try using the staking tool instead of the old race to start the new race on the stem. But, use the old race to completely seat the new race.
In Step 6, you do not need to use the plastigage for every stake. Just use it until you are sure you are hitting the punch with the correct force.

step1.para: Put the staking tool over the bearing race. Cut a one-inch piece from the green plastigage strip and put in between the punch and the staking tool ( Figure 64 - View A). Hit the punch with a two-three pound brass hammer to upset the end of the pinion stem. Then, remove the strip and measure its thickness against the gauge on the wrapper that the strip came in. The strip must not be less than 0.003 inch thick. This thickness indicates that you are using enough force when you hit the punch. If the strip is too thin, then you must hit the punch harder so the stake will hold the race in place. Rotate the tool and repeat this procedure until there are six evenly spaced stake marks around the stem ( Figure 64 - View B).

figure.caption: Figure 64. Put Plastigage Strip Between Punch and Staking Tool

step1.para: With a press or a soft mallet and sleeve, install the outer race and roller assembly into its bore in the carrier. Use a sleeve that is the same size as the outer race and press the bearing until it is squarely against the shoulder in the bottom of its bore.
Apply axle lubricant on bearing cups in the cage and bearing cones.
Install the drive pinion into the bearing cage.
Install the bearing spacer or spacers on pinion shaft against the inner bearing cone ( Figure 65).

figure.caption: Figure 65. Install Bearing Spacer(s) on Pinion Shaft

note.para: The spacer or spacers control the preload adjustment of the drive pinion bearings.

step1.para: Install the outer bearing cone on pinion shaft against the spacer ( Figure 65).

note.para: DO NOT install pinion seal in bearing cage. Continue with adjusting preload of pinion bearings.
